## Voting for far-right parties: demographically

- generally, voting for far-right parties [univariate predictors, e.g., in 11 European countries, @Lucassen2012; also @Bornschier2021; @schaferCulturalBacklashHow2022] ... 
    + [gender]{style="color:darkred;"}: *men* **more** likely than women 
    + [age]{style="color:darkred;"}: *younger* people **more** likely 
    + [location]{style="color:darkred;"}: *rural* residents **more** likely 
    + [education]{style="color:darkred;"}: *less educated* **more** likely 
    + [ethnicity]{style="color:darkred;"}: *migration background* **less** likely 
    + **others**?

::: {.fragment .custom .blur}
- [BUT]{style="color:red;"} it is more complicated in bivariate/multivariate perspectives

:::

## Voting for far-right parties: issue-based

- generally, most important issues for contemporary far-right party voters:
    + [immigration]{style="color:darkred;"}: security (threat perception), cultural change, welfare chauvinism
    + [economic]{style="color:darkred;"}: deprived economic prospects (de-industrialisation), inequality grievances, globalisation's 'losers'
    + [anti-elitism]{style="color:darkred;"}: distrust of establishment institutions (media, longstanding parties, etc.), perceived disconnect and lack of substantive representation by mainstream politicians
    + [gender politics]{style="color:darkred;"}: preference for traditional patterns of social relations, only two genders (i.e., biological sex) and 'natural' gender roles
    + **others**?

## Voting for far-right parties: further explanatory factors

- [public service deprivation]{style="color:cadetblue;"} predicts more far-right support [@cremaschi2024GeographiesDiscontentPublic]
- [place resentment]{style="color:cadetblue;"}: spatial clustering perception of one's region as *excluded* produces similar clustering of populist radical right attitudes [@arzheimer2023PlaceDoesMatter]
- immigrant presence predicts more populist radical right support---mediated by education levels [@arzheimer2024HowLocalContext]
- [presence of stronger dialect]{style="color:cadetblue;"} predicts more far-right (*AfD*) voting [@ziblatt2024WealthTonguesWhy]

<!-- @arzheimer2023PlaceDoesMatter - place resentment -->
<!-- Men’s cultural threat perceptions do not differ from women’s, but men are slightly more Islamophobic, authoritarian, and populist than women. The effect of formal education is much stronger: Having a secondary school leaving certificate reduces the expected value of Islamophobia, cultural threat perceptions, and authoritarianism by about half a scale point. For populism, the reduction is still strong at about 0.3 points. -->

<!-- While the effects of localism are weak and inconsistent, place resentment and the socio-demographic make-up of a place explain a substantial part of the spatial variance of all PRR attitudes. Put differently, respondents who perceive their region as excluded and/or who have socio-demographic characteristics that are associated with PRR attitudes tend to cluster in regions such as the Ruhr or the south of the former GDR, and this clustering produces a similar clustering of PRR attitudes. -->

<!-- @arzheimer2024HowLocalContext - local context -->
<!-- Our analyses confirm that perceived local decline mediates the effects of context on populist and nativist attitudes and PRR voting. They also demonstrate that, while immigrant presence is the most universal predictor of PRR support, its effect is moderated by education levels. While citizens with lower levels of education are affected by the presence of immigrants, those with higher education levels are not. This latter finding fits the broader literature on context effects, which shows that such effects are highly conditional. -->

<!-- Our findings further show that the contextual effects, with some exceptions, tend to be moderated by education. That is, citizens with higher levels of education do not link immigrant presence and economic hardship to perceived local decline, whereas citizens with lower levels of education make this connection. Indirectly, this translates into PRR support. -->

<!-- @cremaschi2024GeographiesDiscontentPublic -->
<!-- Our findings suggest that public service deprivation helps explain far-right support in both settings. -->

- (intercultural) [contact hypothesis]{style="color:darkred;"} *versus* [threat hypothesis]{style="color:darkred;"}
- likelihood of Front National increases in polling stations up to intermediate distances from mosques and then decreases [@dazey2024MosqueNearbyVisible] --- [halo theory]{style="color:cadetblue;"}

<!-- propensity to vote for the Front National increases in polling stations up to intermediate distances from mosques and then decreases, suggesting a spatial mechanism known as the halo effect. -->

## contact & threat hypotheses

- (intercultural) [contact hypothesis]{style="color:darkred;"} - direct contact between members of different groups can reduce prejudice and improve intergroup relations
    + breaking down stereotypes and fostering mutual understanding
- [threat hypothesis]{style="color:darkred;"} - people can perceive their group (e.g., native populations) as being threatened by another group (e.g., immigrants)
    + resources, culture, identity, or power are at risk
    + more likely to develop negative attitudes toward out-group members

:::

## Far-right voting among the youth

:::: {.columns}
:::{.column width="50%"}
[Observations]{style="color:darkred;"}: 

- pluralities of young men voting far right
    + some major young women support too (e.g., AfD)
- youth more left wing in Anglophone countries
- young Europeans more 'right-wing' than US/UK youth on cultural issues like immigration and welfare

:::

::: {.column width="50%" .right}
[Theses]{style="color:darkred;"}:

- Demographic, attitudinal factors:
    + educational gender gap 
    + declining religious salience for women voters
    + polarisation from 'culture war' issues
- two- vs. multi-party systems
- underlying anti-establishment attitudes

:::

## Voter choice, electoral behaviour frameworks

- [institutional contexts]{style="color:darkred;"}
    + especially electoral and party systems
        * how FR parties emerge in two-party vs. multi-party systems
- [demand side]{style="color:darkred;"}: major values and attitudes among electorate 
    + what do voting constituencies want?
    + *who* (groups? from where?) are 'buying' what parties 'supply'
- [supply side]{style="color:darkred;"}: elite competition and cooperation 
    + what do parties offer?
        * ideology and policy (party platform)
        * leaders and representatives

## values & attitudes in brief (Inglehart, Norris, Welzel)

<!-- Pippa Norris on Ezra Klein podcast: <https://podcasts.apple.com/us/podcast/the-ezra-klein-show/id1548604447?i=1000584624028> -->

- Inglehart magnifies Maslow's [hierarchy of needs]{style="color:darkred;"} to societal (macro-) level of analysis &rarr; aligns with groups and their socio-political values and attitudes

![](slide_files/05/maslow-hierarchy.png)

- basic material needs satisfied enables seeking non-material needs

## values & attitudes in brief (Inglehart, Norris, Welzel)

- [materialist values]{style="color:darkred;"}
    + economic growth (maintaining stability and order)
    + security and material needs safeguarded
    + traditional morality
- [post-materialist values]{style="color:darkred;"}
    + freedoms, liberties, rights --- autonomy and expression
    + gender and racial equality
    + environmental protection

- societal groups (existing [cleavages]{style="color:cadetblue;"}) show tendencies towards these values groups: generationally, regionally, class-based, religiously

## values & attitudes in brief (Inglehart, Norris, Welzel)

:::: {.columns}
:::{.column width="30%"}
- [silent revolution]{style="color:darkred;"}: a values shift from materialist to post-materialist 
    + new cleavage [silent counter-revolution]{style="color:darkred;"}

:::

::: {.column width="70%" .right}
![](slide_files/05/materialist_vs_postmaterialist.png){width=90%}

:::

## cultural backlash theory (Inglehart, Norris, Welzel, Dalton)

1. different generations, different experiences, different values
    + Interwar generation (born 1900–45); Baby Boomers (1946–64); Generation X (1965–79); Millennials (1980–96)
2. since 1950s/1960s, national identity, nuclear family, religion &rarr; no longer majority values
3. liberalism expands and traditional values groups feel threatened
4. pushback against liberalism: parties *supply* what is *demanded* by 'disoriented voters' (Norris), many of whom have weaker partisan identification (Dalton)
    + turn to '[authoritarian populist]{style="color:cadetblue;"}' parties <!-- (jettison radical right conceptual focus) -->
    + parties and leaders are appealing for [transgressive behaviour]{style="color:cadetblue;"} (*attention economy*)

## cultural backlash theory conclusions

1. age, education, urbanisation, cultural values [predict]{style="color:cadetblue;"} voting for authoritarian-populist parties in Europe

::: {.fragment .custom .blur}
2. older, non-college educated, rural areas with most authoritarian values drive voting for authoritarian-populist parties
    + *youth votes 'authoritarian-populist parties'* (cleavage forming?)

:::

::: {.fragment .custom .blur}
3. Tipping point thesis: increasing social liberalism threatens socially conservative authoritarian voters (faith, family, nation identities)
:::

::: {.fragment .custom .blur}
4. Effects of economic conditions and social diversity reinforces these threat perceptions
:::

::: {.fragment .custom .blur}
5. Parties/leaders reinforce threat perceptions to mobilise support
:::

## Critiquing cultural backlash theory - @schaferCulturalBacklashHow2022 {.scrollable}
<!-- {.smaller} -->

1. Different age groups have very similar cultural attitudes; few signs of polarisation among old and young cohorts
2. On most topics, different cohorts agree in principle, even though they might differ in degree
3. No positive link between authoritarian values and populist attitudes (measured as political trust); if using a populism scale, cohorts hardly differ 
4. Older *slightly* more likely to vote for authoritarian parties, less likely to vote for populists 
5. Younger more likely to vote for authoritarian-populist parties defined in a more concise way  
6. Interwar generation is the cohort least likely to vote for authoritarian-populist parties 

<!-- Overall, there is little support for Norris and Inglehart’s central claim that older cohorts have more authoritarian attitudes and, as they become a minority, turn towards populism to fend off societal liberalization. -->

# far-right parties' electoral performance - discussion {background-color="#2c844c"}

[[under what conditions do far-right parties perform better at elections?]{style="font-size:95px;"}]{style="color:yellow;"}

<!-- . . .  -->

<!-- - generally, ... -->

## Electoral system and party competition

- [electoral system]{style="color:darkred;"}: proportional representation, low thresholds &rarr; easier to gain seats
- [party competition dynamics]{style="color:darkred;"} [e.g., @carter2005PartyCompetition]: generally, far-right parties can benefit from ...
    + ideological distance from nearest right-wing/centre-right competitor ('political space')
    + being or at least appearing more moderate (contra: AfD, Trump Republicans)
    + ideological convergence between mainstream parties 
    + [hotly debated]{style="color:red;"}: accommodation, adopting far-right rhetoric/frames, exclusion of far right

## Natural ceiling of support? Situational opportunities

- far-right parties rely on voters with nativist, perhaps populist attitudes 
- &#8627; surveys suggest these attitudes hover around 20%  
    + is this a [natural ceiling]{style="color:cadetblue;"} on far-right party electoral strength?

. . . 

Opportunities: 

- [crisis]{style="color:darkred;"} (security/terrorism, economy, immigration) often triggers (*psychological phenomenon*) 'authoritarian response'
- similarly, high [issue salience]{style="color:darkred;"} of far-right '*owned*' issues
- [frustration with mainstream]{style="color:darkred;"} can boost protest votes 

. . . 

[factors/combinations enable far-right parties to surpass 20% ceiling]{style="color:darkred;"}
